posts.sub: How do you quickly become a productive programmer on a project?
posts.com:
Is it about reading the codebase as much as you can (and what if it's huge)? Is it knowing the language/framework and the features of them being used to an expert level?

How do you ramp up / onboard basically?
Assume I have no one to help me (it's not a new job where they'd hold your hand for a few weeks, I'm actually trying to do open source contributions) but I'm reasonably smart, I just haven't tackled large serious projects before, only small school/side project stuff

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>75849593
Small communities are really risky. The smaller the project the more likely it is there's going to be no documentation, and a single set of one-three contributes who make 99% of the changes and have massive King-of-My-Castle complexes. Of course not all of them are like that and you could find a good foothold in one of them and learn a lot, but most likely you're just going to find people unresponsive.

Big, active open source projects seem intimidating but they tend to have (a) tons of minor hotfixes that no one has been assed to get around to fixing (and will often have them categorized as "good for a beginner") and (b) a community used to informing new people because that's how you stay active.

As for how to soft-pitch it's a soft skill, but anything you can say to suggest that you have some familiarity with how the project is working and where it's currently moving towards. Foot-in-the-door kind of thing.

probably not at first because you're gonna spend hours on one project figuring shit out. Maybe a few months in you will know enough about what you're doing you could rake that in.

So for example someone might want you to add a form to their website, you could either charge by hour or give a fixed bid. There's pros and cons to each method.

Charging by the hour means the client can't withhold payment for something they think should have been implemented if they didn't specify it before. They paid for 8 hours of work and you work on it for 8 hours. If they want more they need to purchase more hours so you can continue working on it.

By setting a fixed price you might work 40 hours on something and only get paid the equivalent of like $5 an hour, so you gotta translate your fixed bid into the number of hours you think it will take you to get the price to charge. If the client wants something they think should have been included in the original estimate, they will refuse to pay you because they will claim the feature they paid you for isn't complete yet.

Anyway I'd start with fixed bids because then you don't need to worry about going over the hours they paid for, you just need to worry about implementing their feature for them no matter if it takes you 1 hour or 40. Once you get a hold on how long it takes you to implement things, you could switch to charging by the hour

I'm not very strong in math, but I have an interest in cryptography. I was looking into the "One-time pad" cipher and why it is not as used as other methods are, and I wanted to see if I could come up with something that would patch up some flaws. However, I do question if this idea differs from the "One-time pad."

Instead of incorporating just two keys in the process, this uses a password along with the randomly generated private key to make the public key. Here's my example:


private_key_generated = 5
password_chosen = 10
10 ^ 5 = 15 = public_key_generated

message = 4
4 ^ 15 = 11 = cipher_text

11 ^ 5 = 14
14 ^ 10 = 4 = message

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Standard encryption:
>generate data
>encrypt it
>give encrypted data to someone in public channel that has large throughput
>give key in secret channel
>they decrypt, modify, and reencrypt
>I decrypt it

One-time pad:
>generate data
>encrypt it
>have to give the guy two huge sets of data
>no practical way to do this because the only large-bandwidth channel is compramised
>he can't edit it
>it's generally useless
>you split a thing in two and gave it to someone twice

One time pads have no use except maybe fucking with inheritances in some type of feel-good "work together" shit.

Why on earth are you using vanilla arch for your first Linux distro anon lmao

Use Linux mint if you want to use Debian (stable as fuck, but can be a bit out of date by default)
